Title.evidence: Sacral Neuromodulation vs. Personalized Conservative Treatment for Refractory Idiopathic Slow-Transit Constipation: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised in a 3:2 ratio to SNM (n=41) or personalized conservative treatment (PCT, n=26) using web-based minimization.

Participants.evidence: Participants aged 14-80 years with idiopathic STC, defecation frequency <3 per week, and refractory to maximal conservative treatment were included.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised in a 3:2 ratio to SNM (n=41) or personalized conservative treatment (PCT, n=26).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was treatment success, defined as an average defecation frequency ≥3 per week, measured at 6 months.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomised in a 3:2 ratio to SNM (n=41) or personalized conservative treatment (PCT, n=26).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 6 months, 22 of 41 (53.7%) SNM patients achieved treatment success compared to 1 of 26 (3.8%) PCT patients (odds ratio 36.4, 95% CI 3.4–387.5, P=0.003).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 32 SNM and 8 PCT patients, with 6 serious events in SNM and 2 in PCT.
